metadata.title: Exceptionally high turnover frequencies recorded for a new chitosan-based palladium(II) catalyst

EXCEPTIONALLYHIGHTURNOVERFREQUENCIESRECORDEDFORANEWCHITOSANBASEDPALLADIUMIICATALYST BARAN T 1 Introduction 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Materials 2.2 Instrumentation 2.3 Synthesis of chitosan-pyridil-based Pd(II) catalyst 2.3.1 Preparation of 2,2′-pyridil cross-linked chitosan 2.3.2 Preparation of chitosan-pyridil-based Pd(II) catalyst 2.4 Synthesis of biaryls 2.4.1 Optimisation 2.4.2 General procedure 2.4.3 Recovery and reusability 2.4.4 Chitosan-pyridil-based Pd(II) catalyst in conventional heating system 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Characterisation studies 3.1.1 FT-IR spectra analysis 3.1.2 TG/DTG analysis 3.1.3 SEM-EDAX analysis 3.1.4 X-ray diffractograms 3.1.5 BET analysis 3.2 Catalytic activity of chitosan-pyridil-based Pd(II) catalyst 3.3 Reusability and leaching tests 3.4 Comparison of the catalytic activity of chitosan-pyridil-based Pd(II) catalyst 3.5 Performance of chitosan-pyridil-based Pd(II) catalyst in conventional heating system 4 Conclusions Appendix A Supplementary data References MAKHUBELA 2011 231 241 B KAMARI 2009 296 302 A THARUN 2013 62 65 J COTUGNO 2014 1 5 P BARAN 2015 47 52 T SARGIN 2015 1 13 I MONIER 2016 M MCGLACKEN 2009 4011 4029 G HERRMANN 1995 1844 1848 W JIANG 2012 12121 12139 L FARINA 2004 1553 1582 V BARAN 2015 94 103 T DEMETGUL 2012 354 361 C ANTONY 2013 423 430 R ZIEGLERBOROWSKA 2015 499 506 M ANTONY 2013 53 60 R NAGHIPOUR 2016 39 45 A LITTKE 2000 4020 4028 A MA 2012 2291 2296 H PRIMO 2009 621 627 A JAMWAL 2011 930 935 N COTUGNO 2014 1 5 P BARAN 2016 30 38 T LEONHARDT 2010 30 37 S BARUAH 2015 73 80 D CACCHI 2012 317 320 S SHIMIZU 2002 5653 5655 K SHIMIZU 2004 202 209 K BARANX2016X12 BARANX2016X12X20 BARANX2016X12XT BARANX2016X12X20XT 2018-05-26T00:00:00Z UnderEmbargo http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/ © 2016 Elsevier B.V. Exceptionally high turnover frequencies recorded for a new chitosan-based palladium(II) catalyst Talat Baran a ⁎ Idris Sargin b Ayfer Menteş a Murat Kaya b a Department of Chemistry, Faculty of Science and Letters, Aksaray University, Aksaray, 68100 Aksaray, Turkey Department of Chemistry Faculty of Science and Letters Aksaray University Aksaray Aksaray 68100 Turkey b Department of Biotechnology and Molecular Biology, Faculty of Science and Letters, Aksaray University, 68100 Aksaray, Turkey Department of Biotechnology and Molecular Biology Faculty of Science and Letters Aksaray University Aksaray 68100 Turkey ⁎ Corresponding author at: Department of Chemistry, Faculty of Science and Letters, Aksaray University, Aksaray 68100, Turkey. Department of Chemistry Faculty of Science and Letters Aksaray University Aksaray Aksaray 68100 Turkey Graphical abstract To be industrially feasible, and applicable in synthesis of fine chemicals, a catalyst has to possess high turnover number (TON) and turnover frequency (TOF). In this study, a new cross-linked chitosan derivative was synthesized by using 2,2′-pyridil as a cross-linking agent. 2,2′-Pyridil cross-linked chitosan was used to as a support material for palladium catalyst. Chitosan-pyridil-based Pd(II) catalyst was tested in the microwave-assisted synthesis of biaryls via Suzuki coupling reactions. The catalyst yielded remarkable TONs of up to 20,000 and TOFs of up to 240,964 by using very low catalyst loading (5×10−3%mol) in a short reaction time (5min). The catalyst also showed a better recyclability. Keywords Suzuki coupling Pyridil Cross-linking TON TOF 1 Introduction The reactions of aryl halides with organo-boronic acids are known as Suzuki CC coupling reactions [1]. Chitosan has been widely used as a catalyst support material in the synthesis of biaryls via Suzuki coupling reactions [2]. This versatile natural polymer has free hydroxyl and amino groups. Especially through reactive amino groups, chitosan can be cross-linked easily in order to enhance its metal ion affinity and mechanical strength. These unique properties make chitosan a basic material for homogeneous and heterogeneous catalyst systems. Numerous chitosan derivatives have been tested in different catalyst systems [1,3–5]. Particularly chitosan-based ligands with imine groups are preferred for Suzuki coupling reactions due to ease of production and high metal binding capacity. Cross-linking agents like glyoxal, β-cyclodextrin polyaldehyde and glutaraldehyde have been used to form imine groups within the polymer matrix [6]. Among them, glutaraldehyde is commonly preferred to cross-link chitosan but its toxicity creates health issues. Hence, some researchers attempted to design chitosan derivates using different cross-linking agents to make chitosan more selective to platinum group metals [7]. Due to its high activity in C(sp2)C(sp2) coupling reactions, palladium is the most widely preferred transition metal [8]. On the other hand, the activity of any palladium catalyst is proportional to the number palladium ions coordinated to the ligand. Ligands having more donor atoms (e.g., O, N, S) provide more coordination sites for the metal ion to bind. In this respect, through the condensation of 2,2′-pyridil, which has diketone, with amino groups of chitosan, imine groups can be created. Therefore, 2,2′-pyridil can be used as a new cross-linking agent for chitosan. Due to the diimine groups that are formed via the condensation, 2,2′-pyridil cross-linked chitosan can function as a better ligand for palladium ions to coordinate. Thus, a better selectivity, high turnover number (TON) and turnover frequency (TOF) values can be achieved in Suzuki coupling reactions. Catalysts with >103 TONs are considered as high turnover catalyst (HTC). In a catalyst system, high turnover numbers can be achieved with high product yields and low catalyst loading, and high TOF values can be obtained with very short reaction time. Catalysts displaying high TONs and TOFs are deemed as more economical and practical [9,10]. Such catalyst systems can be transferred from academic laboratories to the industrial applications. Especially high TOF catalysts can be utilized in pharmaceutical and fine chemical applications [11]. This study aimed to synthesize a novel, 2,2′-pyridil cross-linked chitosan derivative to be used as a HTC support for palladium-catalysed Suzuki CC coupling reactions. This new support material was used for production of a palladium catalyst. 2,2′-Pyridil cross-linked chitosan derivative and the Pd(II) catalyst (chitosan-pyridil-based Pd(II)) were characterized using FT-IR, TGA, SEM-EDAX, ICP-OES and XRD. The catalytic activity of chitosan-pyridil-based Pd(II) catalyst was tested in the microwave-assisted synthesis of biaryls without addition of any solvent. In the tests experiments a very low catalyst loading (5×10−3%mol) exhibited better selectivity and gave exceptionally high TONs (2800–20,000) and TOFs of up to 240,964. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Materials Chitosan (448877-250G, deacetylation: 75–85%), 2,2′-pyridil, acetic acid, palladium chloride, sodium chloride, phenyl boronic acid, aryl halides, sodium hydroxide, potassium hydroxide, sodium carbonate, acetonitrile, toluene and ethanol were obtained from Sigma-Aldrich and used as supplied. 2.2 Instrumentation FT-IR spectra of 2,2′-pyridil cross-linked chitosan and chitosan-pyridil-based Pd(II) catalyst were recorded on a Perkin Elmer Spectrum 100 FTIR spectrophotometer. Thermal stability of the products was studied on an EXSTAR S11 7300 (nitrogen atmosphere; heating range: 30–650°C). The surface morphology of the samples was examined on a QUANTA-FEG 250 ESEM. The analyses of palladium and chloride ions on the catalyst were done using an EDAX-Metek. X-ray diffractions of 2,2′-pyridil cross-linked chitosan and chitosan-pyridil-based Pd(II) catalyst were recorded on a Rigaku D max 2000 system (at 40kV, 30mA and 2θ with a scan angle: 5–50°). Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) and Barrett–Joyner–Halendar (BJH) analyses were conducted on Gemini VII 2390 V1.03 (analysis adsorptive: N2; equilibration time: 5s; saturation pressure: 697.426mmHg; evacuation rate: 100.0mmHg/min; sample mass: 0.3590g). Palladium ion content of the catalyst was analysed by using Perkin Elmer Optima 2100 DV Inductively Coupled Plasma (ICP) Optical Emission Spectrometer (OES). Synthesis of biaryl compounds was conducted using a domestic microwave oven. Identification of the biaryls was done by using GC–MS Agilent GC-7890 A-MS 5975. 2.3 Synthesis of chitosan-pyridil-based Pd(II) catalyst 2.3.1 Preparation of 2,2′-pyridil cross-linked chitosan Chitosan solution (2% w:w) was prepared in 25mL of acetic acid solution (2% v:v) and then dropped into a coagulation solution containing methanol (60mL), water (40mL) and sodium hydroxide (12g) to obtain gelatinous chitosan beads. Then the chitosan beads were rinsed extensively with distilled water to neutrality. Subsequently, gelatinous chitosan beads were transferred into solution of 2,2′-pyridil (0.2g) and ethanol (50mL), stirred under reflux for 24h. Finally, yellow-orange product was removed by filtration, washed with ethanol to eliminate unreacted 2,2′-pyridil and dried at room temperature. 2.3.2 Preparation of chitosan-pyridil-based Pd(II) catalyst First, 2,2′-pyridil cross-linked chitosan (0.25g) was suspended in water (25mL). Then, water solution of Na2PdCl4 (0.4g, 15mL) was added into the suspension, stirred for 6h at 60°C. Finally, the yellowish-green product was filtrated out and washed with water. As we conducted synthesis of biaryl in solvent-free media under microwave heating, dried chitosan-pyridil-based Pd(II) catalyst was powdered to increase the surface area on the catalyst prior to use (Scheme 1 ). 2.4 Synthesis of biaryls 2.4.1 Optimisation In optimisation studies for the coupling reactions, we used a model reaction of 4-bromoanisol with phenyl boronic acid under microwave irradiation. We tested optimum conditions for the base system, catalyst loading and reaction time. In the model reaction, the highest yield was achieved with K2CO3 base system (NaOH: 65%, KOH: 78%, K2CO3: >99%). Catalyst loading is the key parameter to achieve high TON and TOF values. 5×10−3%mol catalyst loading gave the highest TONs and TOFs (Fig. 1 ). To determine optimum reaction time, the model reaction was conducted at different reaction times; 1–6min. The highest product yield of 4-methoxybiphenyl was observed at 5min (Fig. 2 ). 2.4.2 General procedure The mixture of phenyl boronic acid (1.75mmol), aryl halide (1.12mmol), K2CO3 (3.75mmol) and the catalyst (5×10−3%mol) in a Schlenk tube was exposed to the microwave irradiation (at 400W) at 50°C for 5min. The progress of the reactions was monitored by thin layer chromatography (TLC). Then, reaction medium was extracted with toluene-water mixture (2:1 v:v) and the organic phase was dried with addition of MgSO4. Finally, chemical identification of the biaryls was done on a GC–MS. 2.4.3 Recovery and reusability At end of the each coupling reaction, the catalyst was recovered from the media by vacuum filtration, washed with water and hot methanol to reactivate. In reusability tests, the reactivated catalyst was used in the model reaction by following the general procedure. 2.4.4 Chitosan-pyridil-based Pd(II) catalyst in conventional heating system To draw a comparison between the microwave heating and conventional reflux-heating, the catalytic activity of chitosan-pyridil-based Pd(II) catalyst in synthesis of 4-methoxy-biphenyl was tested on the model reaction in conventional reflux-heating system. We followed the general procedure as detailed in Section 2.4.2, but here we used solvent i.e., toluene (6mL) and reaction media was refluxed on a heater at 100°C for 24h under nitrogen atmosphere. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Characterisation studies 3.1.1 FT-IR spectra analysis FT-IR spectra of chitosan, 2,2′-pyridil cross-linked chitosan and chitosan-pyridil-based Pd(II) catalyst are presented in Fig. 3 a–c, respectively. The peak appeared at 1647cm−1 in the spectrum of 2,2′-pyridil cross-linked chitosan corresponds to the imine group stretching (Fig. 3b) [12]. Two bands observed at 1582 and 1562cm−1 can be attributed aromatic ring CC stretching of 2,2′-pyridil (Fig. 3b). In addition, we did not observe any bands for carbonyl group stretching of 2,2′-pyridil. These observations confirmed the condensation of 2,2′-pyridil with chitosan via amino groups. In the spectrum of chitosan-pyridil-based Pd(II) catalyst, imine stretching vibration bands were shifted to lower wave number (1628cm−1), indicating that involvement of imine groups into coordination bonds (Fig. 3c) [12,13]. 3.1.2 TG/DTG analysis Thermal stability of chitosan, 2,2′-pyridil cross-linked chitosan and chitosan-pyridil-based Pd(II) catalyst was investigated (Fig. 4 ). As seen in the thermograms, 2,2′-pyridil cross-linked chitosan (292°C) exhibited relatively lower thermal stability than unadulterated chitosan (302°C). This lower thermal stability can be attributed to the decrease in the number amino groups involving in hydrogen bond formation [14]. On the other hand, a further decrease was recorded for chitosan-pyridil-based Pd(II) catalyst (218°C), which is the indication of lower crystallinity of chitosan following the coordination of palladium ion. Additionally, it is highly probable that the presence of palladium ions catalysed the thermal degradation of chitosan chains [15]. 3.1.3 SEM-EDAX analysis Surface morphology of chitosan, 2,2′-pyridil cross-linked chitosan and chitosan-pyridil-based Pd(II) catalyst was displayed in Fig. 5 . After the condensation of 2,2′-pyridil with chitosan, the surface features of unadulterated chitosan changed completely by giving a rougher coarse irregular surface. However, the catalyst showed a regular surface morphology compared to its ligand material. Also, in the EDAX spectrum of the catalyst (Fig. 6 ), the peaks for palladium and chloride ions were observed, verifying the coordination of palladium ions to the 2,2′-pyridil cross-linked chitosan. Palladium ion content of the catalyst was analysed on an ICP-OES. We determined 21.85% palladium content, which was very close the palladium content determined by EDAX (22.82%). 3.1.4 X-ray diffractograms X-ray diffractograms of chitosan, 2,2′-pyridil cross-linked chitosan and chitosan-pyridil-based Pd(II) catalyst are presented in Fig. 7 a–c, respectively. As depicted in Fig. 7a, two characteristics peaks were observed at 10.4 and 19.8°. After cross-linking with 2,2′-pyridil, the peak at 10.4° disappeared and the peak at 19.8° widened (Fig. 7b). The diffractogram of 2,2′-pyridil cross-linked chitosan showed lower peak intensity and crystallinity than unadulterated chitosan. This can be attributable to the decrease in the number of free amino groups of chitosan following the condensation with 2,2′-pyridil [16]. However, chitosan-pyridil-based Pd(II) catalyst had the least peak intensity and crystallinity, demonstrating the amorphous nature of the catalyst compared to its ligand and chitosan. Also, the peak at 40.8° (111 plane) is the indication of palladium ion [17]. This behaviour is in the line with previous studies where the decrease in the crystallinity was ascribed to the metal ion coordination [12,14]. 3.1.5 BET analysis BET and BJH analyses of chitosan-pyridil-based Pd(II) catalyst was performed. The results demonstrated that the catalyst has porous nature (Table 1 ). 3.2 Catalytic activity of chitosan-pyridil-based Pd(II) catalyst The catalytic performance of chitosan-pyridil-based Pd(II) catalyst was tested in the microwave-assisted coupling reactions of aryl halides with phenyl boronic acid under optimum conditions in a solvent-free media (Scheme 2 ). The corresponding reaction yields, TON and TOF values are listed in Table 2 . The coupling reactions with aryl bromides gave higher yields over the reactions with aryl iodides and aryl chlorides. This can be explained by the bond dissociation energies and ionic radii of halides [1]. Due to their poor reactivity, aryl chlorides produced the lowest reaction yields. This observation is consistent with the previous literature reports [18]. As expected, for the all aryl halides the coupling reactions with electron withdrawing groups yielded higher conversation than with electron donating groups. In addition, the position of substituent group on aryl halides affected the reaction yields. As seen from Table 2, aryl halides with para-substituents gave the highest yield, whereas ortho-substituents produced the lowest product yield. Chemical identification of biaryl compounds were conducted by using GC–MS (please refer to Supplementary data for the spectra of the biaryls). The spectra demonstrated that cross-coupling reactions occurred with high selectivity without producing any by-products. TONs and TOFs of miscellaneous Pd catalysts reported in the literature are listed in Table 3 . As clearly seen from the table, chitosan-pyridil-based Pd(II) catalyst yielded moderately high TON and remarkably high TOF. Here in this study, we attained high TONs and TOFs by using a very small amount of catalyst load (5×10−3%mol) with only 5min microwave irradiation. These findings demonstrate that 2,2′-pyridil cross-linked chitosan can be a suitable support material for palladium catalyst from an economical standpoint. 3.3 Reusability and leaching tests Recycle tests with the model reaction under optimised conditions revealed that chitosan-pyridil-based Pd(II) catalyst possessed a better longevity. The reaction yields, TON and TOF values corresponding to each run are listed in Table 4 . We achieved high conversation rates even after 7 runs. At the end of each cycle, negligible activity losses were observed. In the experiments, the catalyst load was relatively low; 5×10−3%mol (3mg), and the catalyst was recovered by filtration from the reaction medium. It appears that some losses in the catalyst amount during the separation are inevitable regarding such a low catalyst amount. Therefore, the losses in catalytic activity can be attributed to the material loss. However, we also conducted palladium leaching tests for the catalyst after seventh run. ICP-OES results revealed ∼2% leaching of palladium ions from the catalyst. This can be another contributor in catalytic activity loss observed in reusability tests. SEM images and EDAX spectrum of the catalyst after seven run are presented in Fig. 8 . Compared to the SEM images of the catalyst depicted in Fig. 5, it appears that surface morphology of the catalyst remained smooth and no aggregation was observed. Also, the EDAX spectrum of the catalyst confirmed the presence of palladium ion even after seven runs. 3.4 Comparison of the catalytic activity of chitosan-pyridil-based Pd(II) catalyst Under the optimised conditions, catalytic performance of two commercially available palladium catalysts PdCl2, Na2PdCl4 and PdCl2(CH3CN)2 were investigated in the model reaction. The commercial catalysts were less effective and their TON, TOF and reaction yields are presented in Table 5 . As seen, chitosan-pyridil-based Pd(II) catalyst showed higher reaction yields, TON and TOF over the catalysts PdCl2, Na2PdCl4 and PdCl2(CH3CN)2. 3.5 Performance of chitosan-pyridil-based Pd(II) catalyst in conventional heating system In conventional reflux-heating system, we recorded low reaction yield and TON and TOF values for chitosan-pyridil-based Pd(II) catalyst (please refer to entry 18 Table 2). These findings demonstrated that chitosan-pyridil-based Pd(II) catalyst is more suitable for microwave irradiation technique. 4 Conclusions This study demonstrated that 2,2′-pyridil cross-linked chitosan is an excellent polymeric support for palladium catalysed Suzuki C(sp2)C(sp2) cross-coupling reactions. In microwave-assisted synthesis of biaryls, chitosan-pyridil-based Pd(II) catalyst yielded outstanding TONs and TOFs. These remarkable TONs and TOFs were attained with very low catalyst loading (5×10−3%mol) in a short span of time (5min). This new high turnover catalyst also exhibited better recyclability by retaining its activity up to 7 cycles. Catalysts enjoying high TONs and TOFs are desired for applications in pharmacology and industrial operations. In further studies, 2,2′-pyridil cross-linked chitosan can used as support material for other transition metals. The catalytic performance of chitosan-pyridil-based Pd(II) catalyst should be tested in palladium catalysed Heck reactions. Appendix A Supplementary data Supplementary data associated with this article can be found, in the online version, at http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.apcata.2016.05.012. coredata.dc:description: To be industrially feasible, and applicable in synthesis of fine chemicals, a catalyst has to possess high turnover number (TON) and turnover frequency (TOF). In this study, a new cross-linked chitosan derivative was synthesized by using 2,2′-pyridil as a cross-linking agent. 2,2′-Pyridil cross-linked chitosan was used to as a support material for palladium catalyst. Chitosan-pyridil-based Pd(II) catalyst was tested in the microwave-assisted synthesis of biaryls via Suzuki coupling reactions. The catalyst yielded remarkable TONs of up to 20,000 and TOFs of up to 240,964 by using very low catalyst loading (5×10−3%mol) in a short reaction time (5min). The catalyst also showed a better recyclability.
coredata.dc:title: Exceptionally high turnover frequencies recorded for a new chitosan-based palladium(II) catalyst
